performance – Performance analysis¶

performance.analyser¶

class orca.performance.analyser.Analyser(alpha, data, index_data=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class for alpha performance analysis.

Parameters:
  • alpha (DataFrame) – Alpha to be analysed. Be sure to properly format the DataFrame as in orca.operation.api.format()
  • data (DataFrame) – Daily returns data properly formatted
  • index_data (Series) – Series of index daily returns that has the same index as alpha. Default: None
IC¶

A dict with key being the number of days, value being the IC time series.

rIC¶

A dict with key being the number of days, value being the rank IC time series.

AC¶

A dict with key being the number of days, value being the Auto-corrwithelation time series.

rAC¶

A dict with key being the number of days, value being the rank Auto-corrwithelation time series.

turnover¶

A Series of daily turnover.

returns¶

A Series of daily returns without any cost considerations.

get_returns(cost=0, index=False)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • cost (float) – Linear amount-proportion trading cost. Default: 0
  • index (boolean) – Whether we measure returns against index. Default: False
get_returns_metric(how, cost=0, by=None, index=False)[source]¶

Calculated metrics based on the daily returns time-series.

Parameters:
  • how (function) – Used in resampling method
  • by – Caculation frequency. None(default): whole period; ‘A’: yearly; ‘Q’: quarterly; ‘M’: monthly
  • index (boolean) – Whether we measure returns against index. Default: False
get_drawdown(cost=0, by=None, index=False)[source]¶

Use get_returns_metric() to calculate drawdown.

get_annualized_returns(cost=0, by=None, index=False)[source]¶

Use get_returns_metric() to calculate annualized returns.

get_perwin(cost=0, by=None, index=False)[source]¶

Use get_returns_metric() to calculate winning percentage.

get_returns_sharpe(cost=0, by=None, index=False)[source]¶

Use get_returns_metric() to calculate Sharpe ratio.

summary_ir(by=None, freq='daily')[source]¶

Returns a IR-related metrics summary series(by is None, default)/dataframe.

Parameters:freq (str) – Which frequency of statistics is of interest? ‘daily’(default): only returns IR1, rIR1; ‘weekly’: returns also IR5, rIR5; ‘monthly’: returns also IR20, rIR20
These metrics are:
  • IR1: mean(IC(1)) / std(IC(1))
  • IR5: mean(IC(5)) / std(IC(5))
  • IR20: mean(IC(20)) / std(IC(20))
  • rIR1: mean(rank IC(1)) / std(rank IC(1))
  • rIR5: mean(rank IC(5)) / std(rank IC(5))
  • rIR20: mean(rank IC(20)) / std(rank IC(20))
summary_turnover(by=None, freq='daily')[source]¶

Returns a turnover-related metrics summary series(by is None, default)/dataframe.

Parameters:freq (str) – Which frequency of statistics is of interest? ‘daily’(default): only returns turnover, AC1, rAC1; ‘weekly’: returns also AC5, rAC5; ‘monthly’: returns also AC20, rAC20
These metrics are:
  • turnover: average daily turnover
  • AC1: average daily 1-day auto-corrwithelation
  • AC5: average daily 5-day auto-corrwithelation
  • AC20: average daily 20-day auto-corrwithelation
  • rAC1: average daily 1-day rank auto-corrwithelation
  • rAC5: average daily 5-day rank auto-corrwithelation
  • rAC20: average daily 20-day rank auto-corrwithelation
summary_returns(cost=0, by=None, index=False)[source]¶

Returns a turnover-related metrics summary series(by is None, default)/dataframe.

These metrics are: * annualized_returns_0: annualized_returns(%) before cost * annualized_returns: annualized_returns(%) after cost * SR_0: Sharpe Ratio for daily returns series before cost * SR: Sharpe Ratio for daily returns series after cost * drawdown: drawdown within the period * ddstart: drawdown start date * ddend: drawdown end date * perwin: winning percentage

summary(cost=0, by=None, group='ir', freq='daily')[source]¶

Returns a summary series(by is None, default)/dataframe.

Parameters:
  • group (str) – Which aspect to be summarized. ‘ir’(default): IR-related metrics; ‘turnover’: Turnover-related metrics; ‘returns’: Returns/PNL-related metrics; ‘all’: All metrics in the above 3 groups
  • freq (str) – Which frequency of statistics is of interest? Default: ‘daily’

performance.perf¶

class orca.performance.perf.Performance(alpha)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class to provide analyser to examine the performance of an alpha from different perspective.

Parameters:alpha – Alpha to be examined, either a well formatted DataFrame or orca.alpha.base.AlphaBase
get_original()[source]¶

Be sure to use this method when either the alpha is neutralized or you know what you are doing.

get_longshort()[source]¶

Pretend the alpha can be made into a long/short portfolio.

get_long(index='HS300')[source]¶

Only analyse the long part.

get_short(index='HS300')[source]¶

Only analyse the short part.

get_qtop(q, index='HS300')[source]¶

Only analyse the top quantile as long holding.

get_qbottom(q, index='HS300')[source]¶

Only analyse the bottom quantile as long holding.

get_ntop(n, index='HS300')[source]¶

Only analyse the top n stocks as long holding.

get_nbottom(n, index='HS300')[source]¶

Only analyse the bottom n stocks as long holding.

get_qtail(q)[source]¶

Long the top quantile and at the same time short the bottom quantile.

get_ntail(n)[source]¶

Long the top n stocks and at the same time short the bottom n stocks.

get_quantiles(n)[source]¶

Return a list of analysers for n quantiles.

get_universe(univ)[source]¶

Return a performance object for alpha in this universe.

get_bms()[source]¶

Return a list of 3 performance objects for alphas in HS300, CS500 and other.

performance.util¶

orca.performance.util.resample(ser, how='mean', by=None)[source]¶

Helper function.

Parameters:how (str) – One of the following: (‘mean’, ‘ir’, ‘sr’, ‘count’). Default: ‘mean’
